texts.shortText: Very large and conspicuous solitary ascidian that forms extensive beds in the low intertidal and on shallow reefs around virtually the whole South African coast. The test (outer covering) is thick and relatively smooth, although it may be heavily encrusted with fouling organisms. When cut it has a rigid whitish inner layer covered with a thin brown ‘skin’. The prominent inhalant siphon points upwards and the exhalent one projects laterally on the ‘shoulder’. The flesh is pink to bright red (hence the common name ‘red bait’).
The largest ascidian in the region with a typical size of about 150 mm height, but can reach at least 300 mm and be as fat as a rugby ball.

Global: Namibia to Mozambique. Many earlier references also report this species from Australia, but those populations are now recognised as comprising several other separate species (P. praeputialis, P. dalbyi and P. sp. See reference below)

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.

A very important species ecologically, dominating the lowest parts of the intertidal and rocky reefs down to a depth of about 10 m, especially in the Cape. Also occurs as loose boulder-like masses on soft substrate in sheltered sites and these are often washed up in large quantities after storms. Red bait beds create habitat for a large number of other species, including commensal copepods, amphipods and crabs that live inside the body cavity. Pyura are also extensively exploited as bait (hence the common name) and are also eaten in some regions.

The structure of the outer test of ascidians is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!

All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the  pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.

Most ascidians are hermaphroditic and although colonial species expand their colonies via asexual reproduction (budding), solitary one reproduce only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults!

Ascidian larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the subratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon, now points upwards.

Pyura species are easy to distinguish from other regional ascidians due to their large size and thick, brown-skinned tests. This species can easily be confused with P. herdmani though, which is very similar in size and habits, but has lobed papillae on the test, especially around the siphons.

Fielding, PJ, Weerts, KA & Forbes, AT (1994). Macroinvertebrate communities associated with intertidal and subtidal beds of Pyura stolonifera (Heller)(Tunicata: Ascidiacea) on the Natal coast. African Zoology, 29(1), 46-53.

Klumpp, DW (1984). Nutritional ecology of the ascidian Pyura stolonifera: Influence of body size, food quantity and quality on filter-feeding, respiration, assimilation efficiency and energy balance. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 19(3), 269-284.

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 113).

Rius, M & Teske, PR (2011). A revision of the Pyura stolonifera species complex (Tunicata, Ascidiacea), with a description of a new species from Australia. Zootaxa, 2754, 27-40.
